      static IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Coalesce(Object[] exprs)
      Returns a coalesce function over the expression list. An expression is either a {@link java.lang.CharSequence} or a {@link java.lang.Number} or a {@link IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef} or a {@link BeforeUpgradeDBFunction}. Note: To use a Coalesce expression in the select list, you must specify the JdbcType
      static IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Concatenate(Object[] exprs)
      Returns a function that uses SQL concatenatation on the given list of expressions. An expression is a list containing either {@link java.lang.CharSequence}s or {@link IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef}s or {@link IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction}s. The objects in the list will be concatenated together to form a SQL expression. For example, the following code creates a function which concatenates a column and a constant. IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column1 = ... IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction columnSum = BeforeUpgradeDBFunction.Concatenate({column1, "some constant"})
      static IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Count(boolean withDistinct, IBeforeUpgradeReadOnlyColumn column)

      static IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Count(IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction function)
      static IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction DateDiff(DateDiffPart diffPart, Object startDate, Object endDate)
      Returns a DateDiff function, used to calculate the difference between two timestamps, expressed in a configurable unit of measure. Note that database difference functions do not adjust for daylight savings time. For example, if you ask for the number of hours between noon on 11/5/11 and noon on 11/6/11, you will get 24 back, even though 25 hours has elapsed.
      static IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction DateFromDatetime(IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column)

      static IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Literal(Object[] exprs)
      Returns a function defined by the given list of expressions. An expression is a list containing either {@link java.lang.CharSequence}s or {@link java.lang.Number}s or {@link IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef}s or {@link BeforeUpgradeDBFunction}s. The objects in the list will be concatenated together to form a SQL expression. For example, the following code creates a function which computes the sum of two columns. IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column1 = ... IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column2 = ... IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction columnSum = BeforeUpgradeDBFunction.Literal({column1, " + ", column2}) Note: To use a Literal expression in the select list, you must specify the JdbcType
      static IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Literal(JdbcType jdbcType, Object[] exprs)

IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column1 = ... IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column2 = ... IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction columnSum = BeforeUpgradeDBFunction.Literal({column1, " + ", column2})

      • Coalesce

        IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Coalesce(JdbcType jdbcType,
                                Object[] exprs)
        Returns a coalesce function over the expression list. An expression is either a {@link java.lang.CharSequence} or a {@link java.lang.Number} or a {@link IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef} or a {@link BeforeUpgradeDBFunction}.
        Parameters:
        jdbcType - The JdbcType of the result of evaluating the Coalesce
        exprs - Expression list
        Returns:
        coalesce function for each of the given expressions, i.e. COALESCE(expr1, expr2, ...). Returns expr1 if only one expression.

      • Coalesce

        IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Coalesce(Object[] exprs)
        Returns a coalesce function over the expression list. An expression is either a {@link java.lang.CharSequence} or a {@link java.lang.Number} or a {@link IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef} or a {@link BeforeUpgradeDBFunction}. Note: To use a Coalesce expression in the select list, you must specify the JdbcType
        Parameters:
        exprs - Expression list
        Returns:
        coalesce function for each of the given expressions, i.e. COALESCE(expr1, expr2, ...). Returns expr1 if only one expression.

IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column1 = ... IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction columnSum = BeforeUpgradeDBFunction.Concatenate({column1, "some constant"})

      • DateDiff

        IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction DateDiff(DateDiffPart diffPart,
                                Object startDate,
                                Object endDate)
        Returns a DateDiff function, used to calculate the difference between two timestamps, expressed in a configurable unit of measure. Note that database difference functions do not adjust for daylight savings time. For example, if you ask for the number of hours between noon on 11/5/11 and noon on 11/6/11, you will get 24 back, even though 25 hours has elapsed.
        Parameters:
        diffPart - What {@link gw.api.database.DateDiffPart} in which to express the difference. Answer cannot overflow an integer.
        startDate - Either a {@link IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef} or a {@link BeforeUpgradeDBFunction} that evaluates to date or timestamp.
        endDate - Either a {@link IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef} or a {@link BeforeUpgradeDBFunction} that evaluates to date or timestamp.
        Returns:
        datediff function for the given start and end dates

      • DateFromDatetime

        IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction DateFromDatetime(IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column)
        Returns a DateFromDatetime function.
        Parameters:
        column - Column to trim to just date
        Returns:
        function which returns date trimmed to midnight

        Returns:

      • Literal

        IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Literal(Object[] exprs)
        Returns a function defined by the given list of expressions. An expression is a list containing either {@link java.lang.CharSequence}s or {@link java.lang.Number}s or {@link IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef}s or {@link BeforeUpgradeDBFunction}s. The objects in the list will be concatenated together to form a SQL expression. For example, the following code creates a function which computes the sum of two columns. IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column1 = ... IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column2 = ... IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction columnSum = BeforeUpgradeDBFunction.Literal({column1, " + ", column2}) Note: To use a Literal expression in the select list, you must specify the JdbcType
        Parameters:
        exprs - Expression list
        Returns:
        a function defined by the given list of expressions.

      • Literal

        IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction Literal(JdbcType jdbcType,
                               Object[] exprs)
        Returns a function defined by the given list of expressions. An expression is a list containing either {@link java.lang.CharSequence}s or {@link java.lang.Number}s or {@link IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef}s or {@link BeforeUpgradeDBFunction}s. The objects in the list will be concatenated together to form a SQL expression. For example, the following code creates a function which computes the sum of two columns. IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column1 = ... IBeforeUpgradeColumnRef column2 = ... IBeforeUpgradeDBFunction columnSum = BeforeUpgradeDBFunction.Literal({column1, " + ", column2})
        Parameters:
        jdbcType - The JdbcType of the result of evaluating the literal
        exprs - Expression list
        Returns:
        a function defined by the given list of expressions.
